content.text:
A 49-year-old man has had marked chest pain for the last 4 hours. An EKG shows ST segment elevation. Laboratory studies show cardiac troponin of 10 ng/mL. The representative gross appearance of his disease process is depicted here. Which of the following findings is most likely to occur in this man? <image 1> 

A. Liquefactive necrosis
B. Caseous necrosis
C. Coagulative necrosis
D. Wet gangrene

The image depicts a heart with a visible area of damage, which is characteristic of myocardial infarction (heart attack). The patient's symptoms and laboratory results (ST segment elevation on EKG and elevated cardiac troponin) also support the diagnosis of myocardial infarction.

In myocardial infarction, the most common type of tissue necrosis observed is coagulative necrosis. This type of necrosis occurs when there is an interruption of blood supply to the heart muscle, leading to cell death and the formation of a firm, coagulated mass.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

C. Coagulative necrosis
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
